title: Conflict Avoidance
description: Explore patterns of avoiding conflict and what's underneath them.

questions.text: When it comes to avoiding conflict, I tend to...
choices: Avoid when I can—it's uncomfortable
Pick my battles—some aren't worth it
Address most things—avoiding builds resentment
Depend on the issue and timing

therapeutic.rationale: Avoidance patterns vary. Frequent-avoiders find conflict threatening; battle-pickers are strategic; addressers prioritize resolution; dependent-types adapt. Some avoidance is healthy; too much builds resentment.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The avoider may frustrate the addresser; the addresser may overwhelm the avoider. Find balance between addressing issues and picking battles.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared avoidance pattern creates aligned approach to when to engage.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How much do you avoid conflict? Is that working for you?

questions.text: When I avoid bringing something up, it's usually because...
choices: I don't want to upset my partner
I'm not sure it's worth the conflict
I'm afraid of how it might go
I'm still figuring out how I feel

therapeutic.rationale: Avoidance reasons reveal underlying concerns. Partner-protectors avoid to spare feelings; worth-evaluators are strategic; fear-avoiders have anxiety; figuring-out types need time. Understanding your reasons helps you evaluate if avoidance is serving you.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different reasons may need different responses. Fear-based avoidance may need safety building; worth-evaluating may be healthy.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared avoidance reasons create mutual understanding about what drives silence.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Why do you avoid bringing things up? Is that serving your relationship?

questions.text: The downside of avoiding conflict for me is...
choices: Resentment builds up over time
Issues don't get resolved
I feel like I'm not being honest
It can come out in worse ways later

therapeutic.rationale: Avoidance costs are real. Resentment-buildup poisons slowly; unresolved-issues persist; inauthenticity damages intimacy; worse-later explosions cause more damage. Recognizing costs motivates change.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different experienced costs can all motivate addressing avoidance patterns.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared awareness of avoidance costs creates aligned motivation to change.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's the cost of avoiding conflict in your relationship? Is it worth it?

questions.text: What would help me avoid conflict less is...
choices: Knowing my partner can hear hard things
Having a gentler way to bring things up
Trusting that conflict won't damage us
Building confidence in my own voice

therapeutic.rationale: Solutions to avoidance vary. Partner-trust needs safer reception; gentle-way needs skills; damage-trust needs relationship security; voice-confidence needs self-development. Naming what would help enables change.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different solutions require different work. Some are about partner response; some are about self-development.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared needed solutions create aligned work to reduce avoidance.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What would help you bring up difficult things more easily?

questions.text: I want my partner to know that when I don't bring something up...
choices: It doesn't mean nothing's wrong
I may need them to ask or create space
I'm protecting the relationship, not hiding
I'm working on being more direct

therapeutic.rationale: Messages about avoidance help partners understand. Something-wrong types hide distress; space-needers want invitation; relationship-protectors have good intentions; working-on-it types are growing. Communicating this creates understanding.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different messages may all be true at different times. Share what's most important for your partner to understand.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared message creates mutual understanding about what avoidance means.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you want your partner to understand about your silence?
